head.title: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Church

hedline.hl1: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Church

abstract.p: Martin Kilson letter finds June 4 article, Shared Prayers, Mixed Blessings, in series How Race Is Lived in America, confirms that African-Americans show greater willingness than whites to extend themselves to broaden ethnic and racial interactions

block.p: Re ''Shared Prayers, Mixed Blessings'' (''How Race Is Lived in America,'' front page, June 4):

Your report about a multiracial church in Decatur, Ga., projected a message quite familiar to African-Americans: that African-Americans show a deeper willingness to extend themselves than white Americans to broaden ethnic and racial interactions in American society.
Re ''Shared Prayers, Mixed Blessings'' (''How Race Is Lived in America,'' front page, June 4):

Your report about a multiracial church in Decatur, Ga., projected a message quite familiar to African-Americans: that African-Americans show a deeper willingness to extend themselves than white Americans to broaden ethnic and racial interactions in American society.

Perseverance by African-American Christians can broaden the world view even of doubting Thomases among whites who lend half their persona to a church's noble interracial experiment and half to America's racist beliefs.
Hailing from a long line of African Methodist clergymen dating back to the 1830's, I share with most African-Americans a deep commitment to our quest to broaden white Americans' racial sensibilities.
The writer is a professor of government at Harvard University.
